very strange Asian work etiquette, I'm not being racist or hold any prejudice against Asian culture, but the "your superior is your master" culture at this bank is really off the charts. 
What do I mean: Your boss sends you a message and you don't reply within 30 seconds? You missed your opportunity because you are not effective and hardworking (actually what it means: you don't show respect to your superior, your superior is your No.1 priority no matter what)

headline: Dont join in
pros:
cant really think of any pros when compared to the other banks I worked at.

Perhaps less pressure since the management does not have a mature rating mechanism. This apparently causes problem and I would rather be rated fairly based on well-established system and careful cooperate planning.
cons:
Incapable management who fully depend on micro-management. They rate you based on things like your response speed to emails (needs to be instantly like in 15 min) and if you make to the meeting they scheduled 30 min ago during the middle of the day. The management have no idea of the actual workload and how many people they need to hire. Basically they cannot plan. 

Some manager ignores your email 90% of the time from day 1 and only responds when feel like to. A lot business as usual things need to be pushed from this kind of manager, which are expected to be streamlined and effortless in other banks I worked at. 

Required to travel to NYC office during COVID in 2020 when it was completely unnecessary. Management dont give a damn about employee safety, but like to claim they do all the time in group emails and announcement.  

Clock in clock out for all full time employees. HR patrol around to see if you work at your desk and follow all rules. 

HR ignore your emails if they want to. Their responses and questions can be highly inappropriate. You experience this during interviews prob slightly and dont ignore the red flags right there. They are totally OK with playing dirty on the back when they need to while pretending to be caring. 

Culture shocks on many aspects (compared to US or European banks). Definitely not diversified staffs and culture. 

Some people were forced to work long hours for a significant period of time.

headline: Worst experience in my life
pros: None whatsoever. The place is a treacherous, illegal operation.
cons: Everything. Believe me when I say that this is a bottom feeding organization that is in no way going to last in the long run. They are unable to hire and retain qualified talent. Everyone from the CCO to the GM to the COO are quite possible some of the most under qualified people I’ve come across. The company is also run by a group of consultants who dictate you life. The worst experience in my 25 year career.

headline: Wished I worked here sooner..........
pros:
The working environment is amazing and the view from the office is something else. 
Friendly and helpful staff who understand and I felt very valued in my tenure there.
CCB had an interesting and diverse culture for an Asian based bank. 
Career progression was good for a smaller bank.
CCB Sydney also truly values the employees work life balance, there was no working from home or long hours if there was no need. 
Access to work on a broad range of projects and I was not siloed like I was working for the Big 4. 
I had access to work with the senior members of staff on end to end projects.
cons:
Hard to think of disadvantages to working for CCB.  
My experience was that CCB offer more fixed term roles to new employees instead of full time. However once the new employee proves their worth they do make them fulltime.

headline: Career destructor
pros: Nothing much can think of. If you have parents or friends or relatives that has strong ties to high profile individuals or government officials or Head of the departments, you will have job security.
cons: Likes to promote inner circles or friends/families of GM/AGM/Head of departments.  Challenging political culture which uses various wechat group to talk down people. Value speed, quantity rather than accuracy and complexity of work. As such mistakes were always found which one can deflate the blame by playing politics. Extremely high turnover which at least 1 person leave every month!  Be aware that you might be promise a very good future (promotion, adjustment to wages within a few months etc.) by signing onto the job offer only to find out that it was a complete lie.

headline: Career Graveyard
pros: There is nothing good about the company.
cons:
Terrible Corporate Culture. Unreasonable request on employees to deliver results/works that is not in his/her profession. Top management is arrogant, lead by ego rather than professionalism. Corporate bullying happen all the time, most China-Chinese expats (usually HOD/Top Management) treat locally employed staffs with little to NO respect and care only their self-interest. Employees are in fear of becoming scapegoat if things turn bad. Bureaucracy is bad, governance is messy, rules or policies are there for nothing. Top management is the rules and policies. Have to possess office-politicking skills to survive.

Inept HR and sub-par benefits. Claim take months to process, employees sometimes have to bear out of pocket expenses that is related to work, leads to unnecessary personal financial stress. Harsh and weird HR. For instances, genuine sick leave can be disapproved and employees are forced to take EL. Have to clock-in on time and strictly 1 hour for lunch. HR may demand for letter of explaination if employees' lunch hours exceed just by 10 minutes.
